uh, notation and nomenclature first. Okay. So a matrix is- it's a rectangular array of numbers,
um, written between square brackets. Now, some people also use curved brackets.
Uh, so that's a- that's a variation that you will see sometimes. So this is what a matrix is.
Uh, it's a square ar- array. And we talk about its size or its dimensions and its dimensions are given by the number of rows,
by the number of columns. So for example, this matrix right here has 3 rows and 4 columns,
so we call that matrix a 3 by 4 matrix. So that's- that's how you would refer to this. It's a 3 by 4 matrix.
Um, now the entries of a matrix, uh, these are the numbers inside, uh, in- inside the array.
Um, these- these- these are called entries, coefficients, or elements of the matrix, right?
And you refer to them by their row and column index. So the row index is 1 for this row- the top row of numbers.
It's 2 here and it's like 3 here. And the column index is like 1 here, you know, 2, 3, 4, that kind of thing.
That- that's how that works. Um, oh, I should mention that the, uh, indexes start at 1.

their index starting from 1. That's something to remember. Um, okay. So if we refer to this matrix up here as B,
then B_ij refers to the ij element.

we have a- we have equality between matrices and we overload the symbol. So there's no special symbol for saying two matrices are equal to the same old equals.
Um, and here's what it means for two matrices to be equal. The entry- first of all, number 1, they must have the same size.
That's the first part. And second of all, uh, the corresponding entries must be the same, right?
So just like a vector. Okay. Um, now matrices are classified according to their shapes.

if here's A, it means that it's got m rows and n columns.

took a constant width, then it would actually be physically a tall, er, the symbol. The way we describe the matrix,
when we write it down would be taller. Uh, it's wide if there are more columns than there are, uh, rows.
Um, and it's square if there's an equal number of columns and rows. So I think these are pretty well- these are pretty well standard, um,
stan- standard terms anyone would- any- anybody in math or applied math or any- any associated field like that would understand, uh, these terms.

C. Now, for them to- they have to have the same height, otherwise, they can't go together.
